choices.text: Galactosemia
Active HSV of the breast
Both A and B
Only A

questions.text: A 30-year-old first-time mother has just given birth to a healthy baby boy and is eager to begin breastfeeding. She consults you for advice on starting breastfeeding. Knowing that breastfeeding can typically commence immediately following a normal vaginal delivery, you review her medical history and note she has untreated tuberculosis, which is a known contraindication to breastfeeding. Concerned for the well-being of both mother and child, you plan to discuss alternative feeding options. Based on this scenario, which of the following are also considered contraindications to breastfeeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both A and B

 

Option C:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Galactosemia in the infant is a rare genetic metabolic disorder where the infant cannot properly metabolize galactose, a sugar present in milk. Breastfeeding is contraindicated in infants with galactosemia because it can lead to serious complications, including liver damage, sepsis, and intellectual disability.

 

Option B: Active HSV lesions on the breast pose a risk of transmitting the virus to the infant during breastfeeding. If the lesions are present on the breast, direct breastfeeding is contraindicated to prevent neonatal herpes, a potentially severe infection in newborns. However, if the lesions are not on the breast, breastfeeding can continue with precautions, including covering the lesions and practicing meticulous hand hygiene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infant with Galactosemia and Active HSV of the breast are the contraindications of Breastfeeding.

 

Absolute contraindications to Breastfeeding are

 

  • HIV in the developed world
  • Active HSV of the breast
  • Mother on radiotherapy
  • Galactosemia
  • Chemotherapy drugs
  • Infant galactosemia

 

Relative contraindications

 

  1. Active untreated TB
  2. Active drug use (Meth, Cocaine, Heroin THC controversial)

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 3793-3794.

questions.text: A mother brings her 3-year-old child, Charan, to the pediatric clinic for a routine evaluation. It is noted that Charan is the second child in the family, and the mother mentions that her first child, who is now 6 years old, has started getting permanent teeth. Considering this information, how many teeth would you expect to find in Charan during your examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20.

 

Explanation:

At the age of 3, 20 temporary or milk teeth are seen.

Rule of six:

  • Primary (temporary) dentition begins in 6 months.
  • Secondary (permanent) dentition begins 6 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition. Page No- From 1198.

questions.text:
An intern is reviewing contraindications for breastfeeding. He must identify scenarios where breastfeeding would not be advisable for the infant's safety.

 

Which of the following conditions is considered a contraindication to breastfeeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

Breastfeeding is contraindicated in cases where the mother is undergoing chemotherapy or radiotherapy due to the risk of passing harmful substances to the infant. Galactosemia in an infant is a contraindication because the infant cannot properly process the galactose in breast milk, and lactose intolerance in an infant would also be a contraindication although it is extremely rare for infants to have lactose intolerance; more often, they might have a temporary lactose intolerance due to gastroenteritis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Mothers undergoing chemotherapy or radiotherapy may excrete toxic substances in breast milk that could harm the infant.

 

Option B: Infants with galactosemia cannot metabolize the galactose in breast milk, leading to serious complications.

 

Option C: While true lactose intolerance in infants is rare, if present, it would necessitate an alternative to lactose-containing breast milk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The contraindications to breastfeeding, includes maternal treatments such as chemotherapy or radiotherapy and certain metabolic conditions in the infant, such as galactosemia.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 1797

questions.text: A healthcare provider is assessing a postpartum mother with a viral infection for breastfeeding suitability. Given the mother's diagnosis, the provider must decide if breastfeeding should be contraindicated. Which viral infection in the mother commonly requires temporary cessation of breastfeeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Herpes Simplex

 

Option C:

 

Herpes Simplex virus (HSV) presents a risk if the mother has active herpes lesions, particularly on the breasts. If there is an active HSV lesion on the breast, breastfeeding from the affected side should be stopped until the lesion has resolved to prevent transmission to the infant.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hepatitis B is not a contraindication for breastfeeding as long as the infant receives the appropriate vaccinations.

 

Option B: Hepatitis C is generally not considered a contraindication for breastfeeding. Transmission through breast milk is not common, and breastfeeding may continue unless there is nipple bleeding.

 

Option D: Varicella Zoster, responsible for chickenpox, is not a contraindication for breastfeeding if the mother has immunity before pregnancy or if the baby has received varicella zoster immune globulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While most maternal viral infections do not prohibit breastfeeding, certain conditions like active herpes simplex lesions on the breasts can necessitate temporary discontinuation of breastfeeding on the affected side to prevent the risk of neonatal transmission.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: In the pediatric clinic, a concerned mother presents her infant, worried about the child's weight gain. She compares her baby to her sister-in-law's seemingly healthier child. Upon examination, the infant appears active and alert. The mother reports that the birth weight was 2600 grams, and currently, the scale reads 5300 grams, indicating that the infant's weight has doubled. As an intern, you recall the standard growth milestones and reassure the mother. Based on standard pediatric growth patterns, at what age is an infant's weight expected to double from birth?
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) 5 months

 

Option D.

 

Weight of an infant doubles by 5-6 months and quadruples by 2 years of age.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The weight of the baby triples by 1 year of age and doubles by 5 months.

 

Option B. The weight of the baby becomes 4 times the birth weight by 2 years of age and doubles by 5-6 months.

 

Option C. The weight of the baby becomes 5 times the birth weight by 3 years of age and doubles by 5-6 months.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51.

questions.text: A concerned mother visits your clinic with her 3-year-old child, worried about the child's inadequate growth. The child's medical history reveals a low birth weight, along with ongoing feeding difficulties and a poor appetite. Upon physical examination, you note several distinctive features: a prominent forehead, a small jaw, a narrow chin, and clinodactyly. These clinical findings, combined with the child's growth issues, lead you to consider a specific diagnosis. Based on the information provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Russell - Silver syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Russell-Silver Syndrome

 

Most cases occur sporadically, chromosome 11p15, maternal disomy of chromosome 7.

Possible risks include:

 

  • Metabolic syndrome.

  • Uterine and vaginal dysgenesis

  • Gonadal hypofunction or testicular cancer in males.

  • Low muscle mass or low bone mineral density.

  • Myoclonus dystonia (in people with chromosome 7-related RSS).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uniparental disomy (UPD) is when a child gets both copies of a chromosome from one parent. This can lead to conditions like Prader-Willi syndrome (if both chromosome 15s come from the mother) and Angelman syndrome.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page 1696, 2987

questions.text: In the outpatient department, a mother presents her 15-month-old child, Mayura, with concerns about the child's lack of teeth. Upon examination, you observe that Mayura has exhibited normal growth patterns, but her oral cavity shows no signs of tooth eruption. Considering the child's age and lack of dental development, you consider the potential causes for this delayed eruption of teeth. What is the most common cause of delayed tooth eruption in children?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Idiopathic

 

Explanation:

 

Idiopathic is the most common cause of delayed eruption of teeth.

Delayed eruption of teeth

  • Delayed eruption is usually considered when there are no teeth by approximately 13 months of age (mean + 3 SD).
  • Common causes of delayed eruption of teeth include:
    • Idiopathic (Most common).
    • Hypothyroidism (Option B)
    • Hypoparathyroidism (Option C)
    • Familial

(Syphilis (Option D) can lead to the formation of prenatal teeth not the delayed eruption of teeth).

  • Individual teeth may fail to erupt because of mechanical block-age (crowding, gum fibrosis).

 

Educational objective:

 

Delayed eruption is usually considered when no teeth have erupted by approximately 13 months of age. Common causes include congenital or genetic disorders, endocrine disorders (e.g., hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism), familial conditions, and (the most common) idiopathic conditions.

 

Ref; Nelson 21st Edition. Page No- From 1198.

questions.text: An anxious mother presents with her child who has been complaining of a toothache. After a thorough examination, you refer the child to a dentist. The dental reports indicate no abnormalities. Following the dental consultation, the mother seeks your advice to understand the difference between temporary (deciduous) and permanent teeth. She is particularly interested in knowing at what age the first permanent tooth typically appears in a child. Based on standard dental developmental milestones, how would you answer her question?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6 years

 

Option C.

 

 The eruption of teeth obeys the Rule of six: -

  • Primary (temporary) dentition begins by 6 months.
  • Secondary (permanent) dentition begins by 6 years.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A and B.  Permanent teeth will not erupt by 2 and 4 years.

 

Option D. Permanent teeth will start erupt by 6 years, by the age of 8 years the permanent teeth will be already erupted.

 

Educational Objective

 

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition. Page No- From 1198.

questions.text: On your first day in the pediatric department, you conduct a routine examination of a newborn in the labor ward. The baby is active and alert. An OBGy consultant comes to assess the newborn, and as she is about to leave, the infant spontaneously grasps her finger. At what age is the grasp reflex, where a baby instinctively holds onto a finger, developed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 28th weeks gestation

 

Option A.

 

The shown image is of the Palmar grasp reflex, which is developed by 28th weeks gestation.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Palmar grasp is fully develop by 32 weeks

 

Option C. By 3-4 months it start to disappear

 

Option D. This is the incorrect option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Palmar grasp onset starts by 28 weeks

 

Fully develop by 32 weeks

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 42.

choices.text: Growth hormone deficiency

questions.text: A 3-year-old child, accompanied by his parents, visits your clinic for a consultation. Upon observation, it's noted that all family members share a similar short stature, which has been a characteristic trait since birth. The parents express their past experiences of discrimination due to their stature but also acknowledge a shift towards acceptance in society. They wish to prevent their child from facing similar challenges and seek your advice. After conducting a thorough examination, you identify limb shortening and disproportionate short stature in the child, indicative of an inherited defect in enchondral ossification linked to an FGFR3 mutation. You inform the parents that the condition is genetic and explain the limitations regarding its alteration. Based on the family history and clinical evaluation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Achondroplasia

 

Option B:

  • Achondroplasia is AD disorder because of mutation in FGFR3 gene,
  • it leads to abnormal enchondral ossification.
  • Rizhomelic limb shortening
  • Disproportionate short stature
  • Champagne glass pelvis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteogenesis imperfecta – will result in short stature but the history will suggest the multiple fractures, blue sclera, skin and skeletal abnormalities.

 

Option C and D.  Both of them will result in proportionate short stature and is less common in familial cases of AD inheritance.

 

Educational objective:

 

Achondroplasia is the most common form of dwarfism characterized by disproportionate short stature, particularly noticeable in the limbs. It is caused by mutations in the FGFR3 gene, which leads to abnormal cartilage formation and enchondral ossification during bone development. This condition is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter – 721 Page No 14374-79

questions.text: A breastfeeding mother inquiries about nighttime feeds and their impact on milk production. The lactation consultant explains that a certain hormone, which plays a pivotal role in milk synthesis, is secreted in higher amounts during the night. Which hormone increases in secretion during the night, making nighttime breastfeeding beneficial for milk supply?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prolactin

 

Explanation:

 

Prolactin, known as the milk-producing hormone, has higher levels of secretion during the night. This is why nighttime breastfeeding is often recommended to help maintain a robust milk supply.

  • Circadian rhythm: Prolactin follows a diurnal pattern with peak levels between 2-5 AM
  • 2-3 times higher at night compared to daytime levels
  • Nighttime nursing sessions stimulate higher prolactin release
  • This helps maintain adequate milk production

 

Other Options- 

 

Option A. Oxytocin: Causes milk ejection (let-down reflex), not production

 

Option B. Progesterone: Actually inhibits lactation; levels drop after delivery to allow lactation

 

Educational Objective:

 

The significance of prolactin in lactation, especially its increased nocturnal secretion, which supports the rationale for encouraging nighttime breastfeeding to enhance and maintain milk production.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 1799

questions.text: A 32-year-old working mother in a multinational company brings her 3-month-old infant to your clinic for a routine pediatric visit. After returning to work postpartum, she expresses a desire to transition her baby from breast milk to cow's milk due to her busy schedule. She inquires about the nutritional differences between human milk and cow's milk, specifically asking which component is present in higher quantities in human milk compared to cow's milk. Which of the following is the correct response?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lactose

 

Option A:

 

Human milk contains higher levels of lactose compared to cow's milk. Lactose is not just a source of energy; it also aids in the absorption of essential minerals like calcium and magnesium and supports the growth of beneficial gut bacteria, which is crucial for the infant's developing immune system and digestive health.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Calcium: Cow's milk actually contains higher levels of calcium than human milk. However, the bioavailability of calcium in human milk is better, meaning infants can absorb it more efficiently.

 

Option C. Protein: Cow's milk contains a higher concentration of total protein than human milk. The protein composition in cow's milk is also different, which can be harder for infants to digest and may lead to an increased risk of allergic reactions.

 

Option D. Fat: While the total fat content may be similar in both human and cow's milk, the composition of fat in human milk is uniquely suited to the human infant's needs, including essential fatty acids crucial for brain development that are not present in cow's milk in the same ratios.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Page No- 145.

choices.text: Mothers and infant to be together for 24 hours a day
Mother to initiate breast feeding within 3 hours of normal delivery
Giving newborn infants no food or drink other then breast milk

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has just given birth to her first child, a healthy baby boy, via uncomplicated vaginal delivery at a local hospital that is known for its adherence to the Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI). She is eager to start breastfeeding and asks for guidance to ensure the best start for her newborn. As her pediatrician, you discuss the BFHI guidelines with her to support her breastfeeding journey. Which of the following pieces of advice would NOT be consistent with the Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mother to initiate breast feeding within 3 hours of normal delivery

 

Option B:

 

The Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI) recommends initiating breastfeeding within one hour of birth, not three hours. This early initiation is crucial for establishing a good breastfeeding foundation, helping to stimulate milk production, and facilitating maternal-infant bonding. The first hour after birth is often referred to as the "golden hour," where uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and the infant's first breastfeed should ideally take place.

 

UNICEF and WHO launched the Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative to encourage health facilities worldwide to better support breastfeeding.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mothers and infants to be together 24 hours a day: This guideline is part of the BFHI and is critical for promoting bonding, facilitating breastfeeding on demand, and helping both the mother and infant to recognize each other's cues.

 

Option C. Giving newborn infants no food or drink other than breast milk, unless medically indicated: This is a core principle of the BFHI. Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for the first six months of life to achieve optimal growth, development, and health.

 

Option D. Encouraging breastfeeding on demand: This guideline aligns with the BFHI's emphasis on feeding infants whenever they show signs of hunger, which supports effective breastfeeding and ensures the infant's needs are met promptly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Baby- Friendly practices

 

  1. Have a written breastfeeding policy that is routinely communicated to all health care staff
  2. Train all health care staff in skills necessary to implement this policy
  3. Inform all pregnant women about the benefits and management of breastfeeding
  4. Help mothers initiate breastfeeding with 1 hour of birth
  5. Show mothers h ow to breastfeed and how to maintain lactation, even if they should be separated from their infants
  6. Give newborn infants no food or drink other than breast milk unless medically indicated
  7. Practice “rooming in” by allowing mothers and infants to remain together 24h/d
  8. Encourage breastfeeding on demand
  9. Give no artificial teats, pacifiers, dummies, or soothers to breastfeeding infants
  10. Foster the establishment of breastfeeding support groups and refer mothers to them on discharge from the hospital or clinic

 

EBF should be initiated as soon as possible (NVD it is 30 minutes)

 

Ref: Op Ghai 8th Edition. Page No- From 97.

questions.text: During rounds with your consultant, several cases of genetic diso rders in the pediatric ward were discussed. Your consultant asks about the most common chromosomal disorder, its complication, and its associated disorders. Match the following columns correctly to demonstrate your understanding and facilitate further discussion:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A2 B3 C4 D1

 

Explanation:

 

 

Some important points

 

  • Nondisjunction - Common aneuploidies seen in live born babies include Down syndrome (trisomy 21), Edward syndrome (trisomy 18), Patau syndrome (trisomy 13) and Turner syndrome (monosomy X).

  • Chromosome deletion - William syndrome (7qll.23); retinoblastoma with mental retardation and dysmorphic facies (13q14.1); Prader-Willi syndrome (hypotonia, mental retardation and obesity, 15qll); Rubinstein Taybi syndrome (microcephaly, broad thumbs and big toes, dysmorphism and mental retardation; 16q13); and DiGeorge syndrome (congenital heart defect, hypoplasia of parathyroid and thymus, facial and palate anomalies; 22qll).

  • Genomic imprinting - Prader-Willi syndrome (microdeletion on paternal side or inheritance of both copies from maternal side) and Angelman syndrome (microdeletion on maternal side or inheritance of both copies from paternal side).

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page 3023-24

questions.text: A pediatrician is reviewing metabolic disorders and their clinical presentations with medical residents. The topic of galactosemia and its associated symptoms arises. Based on the latest updates in medical knowledge, the pediatrician poses a question about the correlation between galactosemia and macrocephaly. Does galactosemia cause macrocephaly?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) True

 

Explanation:

 

Galactosemia is a metabolic disorder that can lead to macrocephaly, among other symptoms. This is due to the accumulation of galactose in the blood, which can affect multiple organ systems, including the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absolute contraindication of breast feeding is galactosemia and it can cause macrocephaly in the baby

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: A mother visits your clinic for a routine evaluation of her 3-month-old child. Upon examination, you note that the baby is alert and active. The child weighs 4000 grams and has a height of 53 cm. To complete the assessment, you decide to measure the head circumference, a crucial indicator of neurological development. Recalling the typical growth patterns of infants, how much does the head circumference usually increases per month during the first 3 months of life?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 cm

 

Explanation:

 

The normal head circumference of a newborn is around 35 cm.

Head circumference is measured by placing a soft non-stretchable tape around the head just above the eyebrows and finding the largest circumference over the occiput. This is 33-37 cm at birth in term babies.

 

 

Method of recording head circumference. Note the crossed tape method

 

Note At birth, Chest circumference is about 3 cm lesser than head circumference and if the difference is more than 3 cm it is an indication of intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR).

Head circumference in the first 3 months of life increases by 2 cm per month, at 3-6 months of life: 1 cm per month, at 6-12 months of life : 0.5 cm per month.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 13

questions.text: A concerned father brings his 8-year-old son, Dev, to the pediatric clinic after noticing his frequent complaints of bone pain and a recent incident where a minor fall resulted in a fracture. During the examination, the pediatrician observes multiple healing fractures of varying ages on the X-rays, along with noticeable bruises on the skin. Initially, there is a suspicion of non-accidental injury, but further assessment reveals Dev has a short stature, distinctive blue sclera, and visible bone deformities in his limbs and spine. These findings suggest a genetic condition affecting bone strength rather than external trauma. What is the pattern of inheritance for Dev's diagnosed condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Autosomal Dominant

 

Explanation:

 

The diagnosis based on the David’s history is Osteogenesis imperfecta and it is Autosomal Dominant in nature.

 

The clinical features include

  • Multiple fractures: recurrent fractures, which can occur with minimal or no trauma. Can cause deformities or shortening of limbs.
  • Blue sclera: Its due to the underlying connective tissue abnormalities.
  • Dental problems: Brittle teeth that break easily or wear down quickly. (Dentinogenesis imperfecta - The bluish, opalescent sheen on several teeth results from genetically defective dentin).
  • Hearing loss: Hearing loss occurs in approximately 20% of young children and as many as 50% of adults by the age of 50
  • Skeletal deformities: scoliosis (curvature of the spine), kyphosis (hunchback), or pectus excavatum (sunken chest).
  • Short stature: due to the impact of skeletal abnormalities on bone growth.
  • Easy bruising: Osteogenesis imperfecta can cause easy bruising or bleeding, particularly in people with severe forms of the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of frequent fractures from minimal trauma, blue sclera, short stature, and bone deformities, strongly suggests Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI). OI is a genetic disorder primarily affecting collagen, leading to brittle bones and a susceptibility to fractures. The majority of OI cases are inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, meaning a single copy of the defective gene from either parent can cause the disorder.

Note - Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) (brittle bone disease) is the most common genetic cause of osteoporosis.

 

Ref: nelson 21st Edition – Page No-14415-14427

questions.text: A mother with a recent diagnosis of tuberculosis is being counselled. She is concerned about the risk of transmitting the infection to her newborn through breastfeeding. The Pediatrician advises her on when it would be safe to resume breastfeeding after starting antitubercular therapy. For how many weeks should breastfeeding be avoided after initiating antitubercular therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Breastfeeding is generally contraindicated in mothers with tuberculosis until they have been on antitubercular therapy for a sufficient period to minimize the risk of transmitting the infection to the infant. The mother should avoid breastfeeding for the initial 2 weeks of treatment, as this is typically the period necessary for the mother to become non-infectious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recommendations for breastfeeding in the context of maternal tuberculosis and antitubercular therapy. Mothers can often resume breastfeeding safely after the infectious period has passed, which is generally after the first 2 weeks of therapy.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: An 11-month-old infant named Ramya is brought in by her mother due to concerns about delayed tooth eruption. Ramya's mother compares her to a cousin of the same age who already has several teeth, while Ramya has yet to have any teeth appear. Understanding the mother's concerns, you explain the typical timeline for tooth eruption and the age at which delayed tooth eruption is considered. At what age should the absence of any erupted teeth be a cause for considering a diagnosis of delayed eruption?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 13 months

 

Explanation

 

Delayed eruption of teeth

 

  • Delayed eruption is usually considered when there are no teeth by approximately 13 months of age (mean + 3 SD).
  • Common causes of delayed eruption of teeth include :- (MNEMONIC – FRIED CAP)
  1. Familial
  2. Rickets
  3. Idiopathic (Most common).
  4. Endocrine (hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism)
  5. Down syndrome
  6. Cleidocranial dysostosis
  7. Progeria
  8. Individual teeth may fail to erupt because of mechanical block-age (crowding, gum fibrosis).
  • Causes of early exfoliation include:-
    • Histiocytosis X,
    • Leukemia.
    • Idiopathic factors.
    • Cyclic neutropenia.
    • Trauma.
  • Nutritional and metabolic disturbances, prolonged illness, and certain medications (tetracycline) commonly result in discoloration or malformations of the dental enamel.

 

A discrete line of pitting on the enamel suggests a time-limited insult.
 

Educational objective

 

Delayed eruption is usually considered when no teeth have erupted by

approximately 13 months of age. Common causes include congenital

or genetic disorders, endocrine disorders (e.g., hypothyroidism,

hypoparathyroidism), familial conditions, and (the most common) idiopathic

conditions.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition. Page No- From 1198.

choices.text: Prader Willi syndrome
Di George syndrome

questions.text: A mother brings her 7-year-old son, William, to the pediatric outpatient department, concerned about his inability to speak and ongoing sleep disturbances. Initially deemed normal developmental variations, the family sought advice from various sources, including a monk, but saw no improvement in William's condition. An intern at a nearby primary health center noticed something amiss during a routine vaccination visit and referred the family for further evaluation. Upon thorough examination, the pediatrician observes delayed development, frequent unprovoked laughter, and an ataxic gait in William. These findings, along with the specific inheritance pattern, suggest a diagnosis of a paternal imprinting disorder. What is the most likely diagnosis given the child's clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Angelman syndrome

 

Option A.

 

Angelman syndrome develops as a result of Maternal Deletion and Paternal imprinting of chromosome 15.

 

Clinical features of it includes;

 

  • Developmental delay
  • Speech impairment: have limited verbal abilities, non-verbal communication methods like gestures, facial expressions, or vocalizations.
  • Ataxia: can affect a person's gait, balance, and fine motor skills.
  • Seizures: Epilepsy and seizures are common in Angelman syndrome
  • Behavioral issues: exhibit hyperactivity, impulsivity, or a short attention span.
  • They may also display a happy demeanor, with frequent smiling, laughing, or hand-flapping.
  • Sleep disturbances: difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep through the night.
  • Intellectual disability: have some degree of intellectual disability, with an average IQ of around 50.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Prader-Willi syndrome: Also involves imprinting abnormalities of chromosome 15 but presents with hypotonia, feeding difficulties in infancy followed by excessive eating and obesity, and mild to moderate intellectual impairment. It results from the loss of function of genes in the paternal chromosome 15.

 

Option C. DiGeorge syndrome: Caused by a deletion on chromosome 22q11.2, it presents with congenital heart defects, immune deficiencies, and facial anomalies, not specifically related to paternal imprinting.

 

Option D. Williams syndrome: Characterized by cardiovascular disease, unique cognitive profile, and distinctive facial features, is not associated with the imprinting issues.

 

Educational objective:

 

Overview of the common clinical and molecular findings in the 8 known imprinting disorders, including specific features, frequencies, and major chromosomal localization.

 

 

Ref: Essential paediatrics by OP Ghai 9Th Edition – Page No-639-641

questions.text:
A 2-year-old child named Mia was brought to the Pediatrician by her mother, who is concerned about her daughter's unusual behavior and developmental patterns. The mother reports that Mia frequently plays with cats and has a cry that is reminiscent of a cat's meow. Upon examination, the Pediatrician observes several notable features: a high-pitched, cat-like cry, developmental delays, hyperactivity, aggression, short attention span, and some distinct facial characteristics. Based on these findings, the Pediatrician suspects Cri du Chat syndrome.

Considering the typical manifestations of Cri du Chat syndrome, which of the following additional findings is most likely to be observed in Mia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Microcephaly

 

Explanation:

 

Microcephaly is seen in case of Cri du Chat syndrome.

 

(Microcephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference more than 3 standard deviations (SD) below the mean for given age, sex and gestation.)

 

Cri du Chat syndrome is seen due to deletion of chromosome 5p

 

Clinical features -

 

  • High-pitched cry: cry that sounds like a cat's meow, which is due to abnormalities in the larynx and nervous system.
  • Microcephaly
  • Developmental delays:
  • Distinctive facial features: variety of facial abnormalities, such as a small head, widely-spaced eyes, a small jaw, and low-set ears.
  • Intellectual disability:
  • Speech and language delay:
  • Behaviour problems: exhibit hyperactivity, aggression, or a short attention span. They may also have social and emotional difficulties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syndromic causes of Microcephaly

 

 

Ref: Essential paediatrics by OP Ghai 9Th Edition – Page No- 26; Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 3034.

choices.text: Less because of small bones
More than expected
Less because of epiphyseal closure due to accelerated growth velocity

questions.text: During a pediatric evaluation, a mother presents her 5-year-old child who is notably shorter than his peers. Upon examination, you determine that the child's skeletal age is younger than his chronological age, which suggests a delay in bone maturation. However, after reviewing the child's growth records, you find that the growth velocity has remained within the normal range. With this information, you consider the probable final adult height for this child. Which of the following best describes the anticipated outcome for this child's final adult height?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Normal

 

Option A.

 

If the growth velocity is normal but the chronological age is more than the bone age, it suggests the diagnosis of Constitutional delay in growth.

 

Constitutional delay in growth

 

  • It is the most common cause of short stature in mid childhood period but the ultimate height is normal.
  • Their birth weight and height are normal. Strong family history of parents having short stature in childhood with delay in onset of puberty is usually present.
  • The average growth velocity is normal and ultimate growth potential is adequate.
  • The bone age is less than chronological age.
  • Upper segment and lower segment ratio are normal.
  • IGF-1 levels tend to be low for chronological age but within the normal range for bone age. Growth hormone and gonadotropin level after puberty are within normal range.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Less because of small bones - This option is incorrect because short stature with normal growth velocity and a delayed skeletal age does not necessarily indicate that the child will have small bones as an adult.

 

Option C. More than expected - While delayed skeletal age can indicate a potential for continued growth beyond the typical age, it does not necessarily mean the child will grow to be taller than expected.

 

Option D. Less because of epiphyseal closure due to accelerated growth velocity - This is incorrect as the child has a normal growth velocity, not accelerated, and therefore epiphyseal closure is not happening earlier than expected.

 

Educational Objective

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 506.

questions.text: A pediatrician demonstrates a feeding technique to a mother who is unable to breastfeed due to a recent surgery. Which feeding method is being demonstrated in the below image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supplementary suckling technique

 

Option A:

 

The image depicts a baby latching onto a device that allows for supplemental feeding while the baby suckles at the breast. This method is often used when direct breastfeeding is not possible or when additional supplementation is needed, allowing the baby to receive both breast milk and additional formula or expressed milk.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Breastfeeding typically involves direct latching to the breast without the aid of devices; thus, it is not the correct answer.

 

Option D: Cup feeding is another alternative feeding method where a baby is fed using a small cup, which is not what is depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supplementary suckling technique helps to maintain the breastfeeding bond and stimulates milk production while ensuring the baby receives adequate nutrition.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 3789

choices.text: If an infant mostly has breastfed and less outside food, it is called as token breastfeeding.
If an infant mostly has other food with no breastfeeds, it is called as token breastfeeding.
If an infant mostly has other food, but still breastfeeds occasionally, it is called as token breastfeeding.

questions.text: A pediatrician is discussing weaning with a group of parents. She introduces the concept of 'token breastfeeding’. Which of the following best describes token breastfeeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) If an infant mostly has other food, but still breastfeeds occasionally, it is called as token breastfeeding.

 

Explanation:

 

Token breastfeeding occurs when an infant primarily consumes foods other than breast milk but still engages in occasional breastfeeding sessions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Token breastfeeding is the practice where infants primarily eat complementary foods but continue to breastfeed on a non-nutritive basis, typically as a means of comfort or routine.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 1795

questions.text: As part of a new initiative, you are tasked with training Anganwadi workers on accurately measuring children's height and weight. During the session, you discuss various aspects of a child's growth, including increments in weight and height. One of the workers asks about specific growth milestones. You plan to inform them about the age at which a newborn's height is typically expected to double from their height at birth. At what age does this doubling in height usually occur?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 years.

 

Explanation:

 

The height of the newborn is doubled by 4 years.

 

Height

 

  • The average birth height is 50 cm. The height gain in the first year is around 25 cm (50% of birth height).
  • The height of a child becomes double the birth height at around 4 years and becomes triple by 12 years of age.
  • After the age of 4 years, a child grows at a rate of 6 cm/year.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 33.
